text:
Is it fairly easy to drive from Florence to Lake Como???

For context, I’m trying to piece together the last leg of our honeymoon late September. We will be leaving our 4 night stay in Florence and going to Menaggio on Lake Como for our last 3 nights, then flying home out of Milan, 4 pm flight so plenty of time to get there from Menaggio that day.

In piecing together the routes, it looks like I have a few options -

1. Train Florence to Milan, Milan to Varenna, then Ferry to Menaggio

2. Train Florence to Milan, Milan to Como, then Ferry or Bus to Menaggio

3. Pick up rental car at Florence airport, drive there (free parking at our hotel) and use it to get us to MXP when flying out our last day.

I know the trains are typically the way to go, and if we were staying in Varenna, I would have done this no doubt. But after pieceing all of the legs together, due to train and ferry or bus times, the first two options will take us about 7 hours, and that’s if everything leaves on time. I’ve heard trains can be delayed often and if so that would put us back another hour or two.

I like the idea of just getting in a car (I’ve read picking up at the airport is the way to go) and having it as an option to get us to MXP on our way back. Maybe stopping in Bologna for lunch on the way or somewhere else? The drive time looks like about 4 hours versus 7+ with public transport.

I’ve driven in Portugal with no issues. This would be the only portion of our trip with a car. Looking for some reassurance it would be fairly “easy”? We’d likely pick up in Florence first thing in the morning.

comments.comment_text:
I lived in Florence this summer. I rented a car to
go to The Dolomites. I actually rented through Avis and picked it up in the city so I didn’t have to truck out to the airport, but returned it to the airport.
1. Get your international drivers license - 20-30 at any AAA in the US.
2. Always get your ticket when getting in the autostrada. Make sure to go in the lanes marked to pay with card when exiting (not the yellow telepass lane) .
I found it very easy, fun, beautiful to drive through Tuscany. There are many towns to get off to grab lunch. Just know ahead if you are going somewhere with a ZTL and park outside it and bus or train in if needed. Small towns don’t have them frequently.
Option 3, definitely.

Yes, really easy to drive in this part of Italy. The highways are straightforward
and the smaller roads all well marked. If you’ve driven in Portugal you’ll find it similar (except in Italy people generally drive faster and those German cars on the autostrada will crawl up right on your bumper and want you to get over if you’re not doing 140km/h. 😂 ) Parking could be annoying for that lunch stop in Bologna but as long as you’re not trying to enter the very core of the historic part of the city, it’s doable. Go for it!

It’s definitely easy, in Italy we say “è tutta autostrada!!” (Meaning “it’s all highway” = it’s easy, fast, straight).
The “difficult” part will be driving around lake Como as the streets are small and parking is a nightmare.
Do you have a parking lot at your hotel in menaggio?
Also consider traffic around Milan/Lombardy in general (add 30 mins to 1hr)

It’s a lot of beautiful driving, I would get a car. You could go through Bologna, Modena, Piacenza, Parma, then from Como could venture into Switzerland, just make sure you get the Swiss sticker for your car
I think you have answered your own question but if was me I would take option 1.
